title: H.S. girls soccer: Hating penalty kicks
text:
Clifton’s Brittany Morales scoring against Lakeland last week in a shootout that the Mustangs won. 
Kelly Redl refused to take another shootout penalty kick. 
Ever. 
The former Ramsey soccer player was just a ninth-grader playing in a freshman game when her attempt was denied by an opposing goalkeeper in a loss. The pain stung so severely that it made a lasting impact on the rest of her high school career. 
Redl, a 2014 graduate and All-Bergen County-caliber defender, would not even practice penalty kicks again until her senior season. 
"And I still wouldn’t make them," she said, laughing. "I don’t know if it was that I couldn’t handle the pressure, but if I missed, I’d probably lose it and go crazy." 
Standing one-on-one against a focused goalkeeper who is staring her down from 12 yards away was something Redl wanted no part of ever again. And she’s not alone. It’s a mind-set shared by several current North Jersey stars, according to area coaches, especially when a game – and maybe even a season – is at stake. 
There’s just something about penalty kicks that make even some of the most talented of players unable to get past the mental roadblock. 
"Oh, I don’t like them at all," said Mahwah junior Sarah Jordan, who stays away from penalty kicks despite being one of North Jersey’s top facilitating playmakers (nine goals, 14 assists). "I think I’d just be too hard on myself and blame myself too much if I didn’t come through. I don’t want to let the team down." 
Some penalty kicks have storybook endings. Others have nightmarish finishes. That is the stark reality of these pressure-packed shootouts. 
Shooter vs. goalie. One wins. One loses. And everyone else watches intently. 
Not wanting to place responsibility on any one player for a loss is partially why the Bergen and Passaic County championship soccer games – and the state finals – don’t go to penalty kicks. 
"If two teams are tied at the end of 100 minutes, do you really want to determine a winner by PKs?" said Paul Heenehan, the Ramapo coach and Bergen County tournament director. 
So both counties and the NJSIAA award co-champions, which often leaves both teams with mixed emotions and no closure. 
But all the rounds leading up to the championships in the aforementioned tournaments do need advancement. So, they settle knotted games with drama-filled shootouts. 
The winner in penalty kicks is not always indicative of the better team. But it is the only plausible solution right now, officials say. 
"The way it is now is not totally satisfactory," said Ramsey coach George Wright, whose program was on both ends of penalty kicks in 2013, winning a sectional title at Pascack Hills in a shootout then losing in the same fashion five days later in the Group 2 semifinals. "No one really likes ending games in shootouts. 
"But no one really has any other alternative." 
Ridgewood, Paramus, Paramus Catholic and Clifton all have won county tournament shootouts this season. The Maroons and Mustangs are vying for their respective county titles. 
Most believe the kicks themselves pose more of a mental challenge than a physical one. Differing from the usual pace of play in soccer, shootouts allow its participants significantly more time to ponder the consequences of failure. 
There’s the long walk to the spot of the kick. The placement of the ball on the line. The staredown with the goalie. The wait for the whistle to blow. 
It’s all about confidence in the moment. © 2015 North Jersey Media Group Tags:
